disease_description: Leigh syndrome is a severe neurological disorder that can begin at any time in life. Symptoms vary among affected individuals and can affect multiple body systems.
onset_information: Symptoms of this disease may start to appear at any time in life. This includes prenatal, newborn, infant, child, adolescent, adult, and older adult stages.
body_systems_impact: Symptoms related to Leigh syndrome may affect different systems of the body.

chatbot_guidance.symptom_list_intro: The following list provides symptoms associated with Leigh syndrome. Each symptom entry includes a description, synonyms, affected body systems, and frequency among confirmed cases of Leigh syndrome. This is not an exhaustive list—some symptoms may not be listed.
prioritization_rules: If a user asks about a disease's symptoms, provide those with higher 'Frequency' values first and limit the list to 10, unless requested to provide more.

If a user asks about a specific body system, refer to the 'Body System Category(-ies)' values and match accordingly. Provide higher frequency symptoms first and limit the list to 10, unless requested otherwise.
If a user asks about common versus uncommon symptoms, refer to the 'Frequency' value to determine relevance.
chatbot_guidance.individual_experience_disclaimer: The types of symptoms experienced, and their intensity, may vary among people with this disease. Your experience may be different from others. Consult your healthcare team for more information.

body_systems.blood_and_blood_forming_tissue: The blood and blood-forming tissue includes plasma, red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets, and bone marrow.
body_systems.cardiovascular_system: The cardiovascular system is made up of the heart and blood vessels, including the arteries, veins, and capillaries.
body_systems.digestive_system: The digestive system is made up of the esophagus, stomach, intestines, liver, pancreas, and gallbladder.
body_systems.immune_system: The immune system is a complex network of cells, tissues, and organs that together help the body fight infections and other diseases.
body_systems.musculoskeletal_system: The musculoskeletal system is made up of the bones, muscles, and joints.
body_systems.nervous_system: The nervous system is made up of the brain, spinal cord, and nerves.
body_systems.respiratory_system: The respiratory system is made up of the lungs and the nose, mouth, throat, voice box, windpipe, diaphragm, and muscles of the chest wall.
body_systems.skin_system: The skin or integumentary system is made up of skin, hair, nails, sweat glands, and oil glands.

symptoms.name: Renal tubular dysfunction
synonyms: Abnormal function of filtrating structures in kidney
symptoms.description: Abnormal function of the renal tubule. The basic functional unit of the kidney, the nephron, consists of a renal corpuscle attached to a renal tubule, with roughly 0.8 to 1.5 nephrons per adult kidney. The functions of the renal tubule include reabsorption of water, electrolytes, glucose, and amino acids and secretion of substances such as uric acid.

symptoms.name: Optic atrophy
symptoms.description: Atrophy of the optic nerve. Optic atrophy results from the death of the retinal ganglion cell axons that comprise the optic nerve and manifesting as a pale optic nerve on fundoscopy.

symptoms.name: Spasticity
synonyms: Involuntary muscle stiffness, contraction, or spasm
symptoms.description: A motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes.

symptoms.name: Spastic diplegia
symptoms.description: Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis.

symptoms.name: Cerebellar atrophy
symptoms.description: Cerebellar atrophy is defined as a cerebellum with initially normal structures, in a posterior fossa with normal size, which displays enlarged fissures (interfolial spaces) in comparison to the foliae secondary to loss of tissue. Cerebellar atrophy implies irreversible loss of tissue and result from an ongoing progressive disease until a final stage is reached or a single injury, e.g. an intoxication or infectious event.

symptoms.name: Dystonia
symptoms.description: An abnormally increased muscular tone that causes fixed abnormal postures. There is a slow, intermittent twisting motion that leads to exaggerated turning and posture of the extremities and trunk.

symptoms.name: Failure to thrive
symptoms.description: Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm.

symptoms.name: Intrauterine growth retardation
symptoms.description: An abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age.

symptoms.name: Ventricular septal defect
synonyms: Hole in heart wall separating two lower heart chambers
symptoms.description: A hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.

symptoms.name: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
symptoms.description: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is defined by the presence of increased ventricular wall thickness or mass in the absence of loading conditions (hypertension, valve disease) sufficient to cause the observed abnormality.

symptoms.name: Abnormality of extrapyramidal motor function
symptoms.description: A neurological condition related to lesions of the basal ganglia leading to typical abnormalities including akinesia (inability to initiate changes in activity and perform volitional movements rapidly and easily), muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement), chorea (widespread arrhythmic movements of a forcible, rapid, jerky, and restless nature), athetosis (inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers, toes, or other group of muscles in a fixed position), and akathisia (inability to remain motionless).

symptoms.name: Hypoplasia of the corpus callosum
synonyms: Underdevelopment of part of brain called corpus callosum
symptoms.description: Underdevelopment of the corpus callosum.

symptoms.name: Gliosis
symptoms.description: Gliosis is the focal proliferation of glial cells in the central nervous system.

symptoms.name: Leukodystrophy
synonyms: Degeneration of white matter of brain
symptoms.description: Leukodystrophy refers to deterioration of white matter of the brain resulting from degeneration of myelin sheaths in the CNS. Their basic defect is directly related to the synthesis and maintenance of myelin membranes. Symmetric white matter involvement at MRI is a typical finding in patients with leukodystrophies.

symptoms.name: Sensory axonal neuropathy
symptoms.description: An axonal neuropathy of peripheral sensory nerves.

symptoms.name: Involuntary movements
symptoms.description: Involuntary contractions of muscle leading to involuntary movements of extremities, neck, trunk, or face.

symptoms.name: Diffuse spongiform leukoencephalopathy
symptoms.description: Not specified

symptoms.name: Severe viral infection
symptoms.description: An unusually severe viral infection.

symptoms.name: Abnormality of movement
symptoms.description: An abnormality of movement with a neurological basis characterized by changes in coordination and speed of voluntary movements.

symptoms.name: Neuronal loss in basal ganglia
symptoms.description: A reduction in the number of nerve cells in the basal ganglia.

symptoms.name: Macrotia
symptoms.description: Median longitudinal ear length greater than two standard deviations above the mean and median ear width greater than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparent increase in length and width of the pinna (subjective).

symptoms.name: Ophthalmoplegia
symptoms.description: Paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles that are responsible for eye movements.

symptoms.name: Nystagmus
symptoms.description: Rhythmic, involuntary oscillations of one or both eyes related to abnormality in fixation, conjugate gaze, or vestibular mechanisms.

symptoms.name: Eczema
symptoms.description: Eczema is a form of dermatitis. The term eczema is broadly applied to a range of persistent skin conditions and can be related to a number of underlying conditions. Manifestations of eczema can include dryness and recurring skin rashes with redness, skin edema, itching and dryness, crusting, flaking, blistering, cracking, oozing, or bleeding.

symptoms.name: Agenesis of corpus callosum
symptoms.description: Absence of the corpus callosum as a result of the failure of the corpus callosum to develop, which can be the result of a failure in any one of the multiple steps of callosal development including cellular proliferation and migration, axonal growth or glial patterning at the midline.

symptoms.name: Growth delay
symptoms.description: A deficiency or slowing down of growth pre- and postnatally.

symptoms.name: Congestive heart failure
symptoms.description: The presence of an abnormality of cardiac function that is responsible for the failure of the heart to pump blood at a rate that is commensurate with the needs of the tissues or a state in which abnormally elevated filling pressures are required for the heart to do so. Heart failure is frequently related to a defect in myocardial contraction.

symptoms.name: Anemia
synonyms: Low number of red blood cells or hemoglobin
symptoms.description: A reduction in erythrocytes volume or hemoglobin concentration.

symptoms.name: Abnormal facial shape
symptoms.description: An abnormal morphology (form) of the face or its components.

symptoms.name: Dysphagia
symptoms.description: Difficulty in swallowing.

symptoms.name: Chorea
symptoms.description: Chorea (Greek for 'dance') refers to widespread arrhythmic involuntary movements of a forcible, jerky and restless fashion. It is a random-appearing sequence of one or more discrete involuntary movements or movement fragments. Movements appear random because of variability in timing, duration or location. Each movement may have a distinct start and end. However, movements may be strung together and thus may appear to flow randomly from one muscle group to another. Chorea can involve the trunk, neck, face, tongue, and extremities.

symptoms.name: Status epilepticus
synonyms: Repeated seizures without recovery between them
symptoms.description: Status epilepticus is a type of prolonged seizure resulting either from the failure of the mechanisms responsible for seizure termination or from the initiation of mechanisms which lead to abnormally prolonged seizures (after time point t1). It is a condition that can have long-term consequences (after time point t2), including neuronal death, neuronal injury, and alteration of neuronal networks, depending on the type and duration of seizures.

symptoms.name: Distal muscle weakness
synonyms: Muscle weakness, distal limbs, due to neuronopathy
symptoms.description: Reduced strength of the musculature of the distal extremities.

symptoms.name: Increased CSF lactate
symptoms.description: Increased concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid.

symptoms.name: Psychomotor retardation
symptoms.description: Not specified

symptoms.name: Encephalomalacia
symptoms.description: Encephalomalacia is the softening or loss of brain tissue after cerebral infarction, cerebral ischemia, infection, craniocerebral trauma, or other injury.

symptoms.name: Nephrotic syndrome
symptoms.description: Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of findings resulting from glomerular dysfunction with an increase in glomerular capillary wall permeability associated with pronounced proteinuria. Nephrotic syndrome refers to the constellation of clinical findings that result from severe renal loss of protein, with Proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.

symptoms.name: Ptosis
symptoms.description: The upper eyelid margin is positioned 3 mm or more lower than usual and covers the superior portion of the iris (objective); or, the upper lid margin obscures at least part of the pupil (subjective).

symptoms.name: Abnormality of the skeletal system
symptoms.description: An abnormality of the skeletal system.

symptoms.name: Ataxia
symptoms.description: Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- or overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly).

symptoms.name: Choreoathetosis
symptoms.description: Involuntary movements characterized by both athetosis (inability to sustain muscles in a fixed position) and chorea (widespread jerky arrhythmic movements).

symptoms.name: Hepatic failure
symptoms.description: Not specified

symptoms.name: Neutropenia
symptoms.description: An abnormally low number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood.

symptoms.name: Progressive neurologic deterioration
symptoms.description: Not specified

symptoms.name: Hyperkinetic movements
symptoms.description: Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole.

symptoms.name: Olivopontocerebellar atrophy
symptoms.description: Neuronal degeneration in the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus.

symptoms.name: Respiratory failure
symptoms.description: A severe form of respiratory insufficiency characterized by inadequate gas exchange such that the levels of oxygen or carbon dioxide cannot be maintained within normal limits.

symptoms.name: Myopathy
symptoms.description: A disorder of muscle unrelated to impairment of innervation or neuromuscular junction.

symptoms.name: Peripheral neuropathy
symptoms.description: Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course.

symptoms.name: Frontal hirsutism
symptoms.description: Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead.

symptoms.name: Feeding difficulties
symptoms.description: Impaired ability to eat related to problems gathering food and getting ready to suck, chew, or swallow it.

symptoms.name: Infantile spasms
symptoms.description: Infantile spasms represent a subset of \"epileptic spasms\". Infantile Spasms are epileptic spasms starting in the first year of life (infancy).

symptoms.name: Abnormal dentate nucleus morphology
symptoms.description: An abnormality of the dentate nucleus.

symptoms.name: High forehead
symptoms.description: An abnormally increased height of the forehead.

symptoms.name: Sensorineural hearing impairment
symptoms.description: A type of hearing impairment in one or both ears related to an abnormal functionality of the cochlear nerve.

symptoms.name: Cataract
synonyms: Clouding of the lens of the eye
symptoms.description: A cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the crystalline lens of the eye or in its capsule.

symptoms.name: Abnormality of the optic nerve
symptoms.description: Abnormality of the optic nerve.

symptoms.name: Hypertrichosis
symptoms.description: Hypertrichosis is increased hair growth that is abnormal in quantity or location.

symptoms.name: Seizure
symptoms.description: A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.

symptoms.name: Muscle weakness
symptoms.description: Reduced strength of muscles.

symptoms.name: Alopecia
symptoms.description: A noncongenital process of hair loss, which may progress to partial or complete baldness.

symptoms.name: Athetosis
synonyms: Involuntary writhing movements in fingers, hands, toes, and feet
symptoms.description: A slow, continuous, involuntary writhing movement that prevents maintenance of a stable posture. Athetosis involves continuous smooth movements that appear random and are not composed of recognizable sub-movements or movement fragments. In contrast to chorea, in athetosis, the same regions of the body are repeatedly involved. Athetosis may worsen with attempts at movement of posture, but athetosis can also occur at rest.

symptoms.name: Developmental regression
symptoms.description: Loss of developmental skills, as manifested by loss of developmental milestones.

symptoms.name: Upper motor neuron dysfunction
symptoms.description: A functional anomaly of the upper motor neuron. The upper motor neurons are neurons of the primary motor cortex which project to the brainstem and spinal chord via the corticonuclear, corticobulbar and corticospinal (pyramidal) tracts. They are involved in control of voluntary movements. Dysfunction leads to weakness, impairment of fine motor movements, spasticity, hyperreflexia and abnormal pyramidal signs.

symptoms.name: Gastrointestinal dysmotility
symptoms.description: Abnormal intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis, related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.

symptoms.name: Abnormal pattern of respiration
symptoms.description: An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing.

symptoms.name: Multiple joint contractures
symptoms.description: Not specified

symptoms.name: Skeletal muscle atrophy
synonyms: Neurogenic muscle atrophy, especially in the lower limbs
symptoms.description: The presence of skeletal muscular atrophy (which is also known as amyotrophy).

symptoms.name: Infantile muscular hypotonia
symptoms.description: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in infancy.

symptoms.name: Dyskinesia
symptoms.description: A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.

symptoms.name: Brain imaging abnormality
symptoms.description: An anomaly of metabolism or structure of the brain identified by imaging.
